'''Steve Nardella''' (born June 26, 1948, [[Providence, Rhode Island]], United States)<ref name="AMG"/> is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]], [[rock and roll]], [[blues rock]] and [[rockabilly]]  [[guitarist]] and [[singing|singer]]. [[Allmusic]] [[music journalism|journalist]], [[Cub Koda]], stated Nardella is a "strong, American roots-music performer, equally adept at rockabilly and low-down blues."<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Nardella became proficient on both guitar and harmonica by his late teens, and by the late 1960s was in the Black Cat Blues Band with [[Duke Robillard]], [[Johnny Nicholas]] and Fran Christina. By 1971 Nardella, Nicholas and Christina had all relocated to [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]].<ref name="Kettle"/> Nardella then instigated the Boogie Brothers band with Sarah Brown, Nicholas and Christina. They backed a variety of blues musicians who toured locally, and were on the bill at the 1972 [[Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festival]], both as backing to [[Johnny Shines]] and [[Boogie Woogie Red]], plus in their own right.<ref name="AMG"/> Their work appeared on the [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]] [[album]], ''Ann Arbor Blues & Jazz Festival: 1972''.<ref name="Kettle"/><ref name="Atlantic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ann-arbor-blues-jazz-festival-1972-atlantic-mw0001341291 |title=Ann Arbor Blues & Jazz Festival: 1972 [Atlantic] - Various Artists | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>

By the following year, the band name had changed to the Vipers and included the guitarist George Bedard.  Their single, "Huron River Drive," was the first record to be released by [[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]].<ref name="Kettle"/> In 1974, Nardella backed [[Bobo Jenkins]] on his album ''Here I Am a Fool in Love Again''. Other [[session musician]]s used included Brown and Christina.<ref name="Bobo">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=bobo-jenkins-p188318/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Bobo Jenkins |author=Reif, Fred |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 16, 2010}}</ref>

Nardella and Bedard then formed the Silvertones, who toured across the [[United States|US]], and released the 1977 album, ''One Chance With You'', also on Blind Pig.  In addition to his harmonica playing, Nardella introduced more of his own guitar work and singing to their output.<ref name="Kettle"/> With a change of personnel, in 1979 the renamed Steve Nardella Band issued, ''It's All Rock & Roll''.<ref name="AMG"/> The Steve Nardella Band lasted from 1978 to 1984.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://blog.mlive.com/encorea2/2008/05/preview_steve_nardella_band_re.html |title=PREVIEW: Steve Nardella Band reunion at the Firefly Club | MLive.com |publisher=Blog.mlive.com |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>

Nardella eventually became a solo artist and for years both toured and played backing to other musicians.  His next album, ''Daddy Rollin' Stone'' did not appear until 1993.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=steve-nardella-p475/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Steve Nardella|author=[[Cub Koda|Koda, Cub]] |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=November 16, 2010}}</ref> The same year, Nardella's trio backed [[Eddie "Guitar" Burns|Eddie Burns]] on his [[Scandinavia]]n tour. Nardella also led the touring backing band for [[Jack Scott (singer)|Jack Scott]].<ref name="Kettle">{{cite web|url=http://blackkettleproductions.com/?p=14 |title=Steve Nardella|publisher=Blackkettleproductions.com|accessdate=November 16, 2010}}</ref>

In June 2008, Nardella, Bedard and their one time band pianist Mr. B (Mark Lincoln Braun), played a reunion concert in Ann Arbor's Firefly Club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guitarvibe.com/2008/06/steve-nardella.html |title=Steve Nardella, George Bedard, Mr. B Reunion Gig |publisher=GuitarVibe.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref> Nardella, with varying backing musicians,  continues to perform live.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arborweb.com/articles/steve_nardella_full_article.html |title=Steve Nardella - Ann Arbor Observer |publisher=Arborweb.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}</ref>
